video.title: Full HTTP Networking Course – Fetch and REST APIs in JavaScript
video.description:
Master the HTTP networking protocol by completing over 80 coding exercises and quizzes in JavaScript. Once you’ve learned it all, we’ll build a real web crawler using Node.js to put all the concepts into practice.

HTTP is the backbone of the modern web, and in this course we’ll do a deep dive into all of the fundamentals you’ll need to know to master web networking. We’ll use the Fetch API to interact with a live RESTful server in order to connect the different components of a video game.

💻 Code: https://github.com/bootdotdev/fcc-learn-http-assets

🔗 Follow this course interactively on Boot.dev: https://boot.dev/learn/learn-http

✏️ Lane Wagner created this course.
Boot.dev: https://boot.dev
Lane on Twitter: https://twitter.com/wagslane
Lane’s YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/@bootdotdev
New to JavaScript? Beginner course: https://boot.dev/learn/learn-javascript

⭐️ Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:03:32) Ch 1 - Why HTTP
⌨️ (0:27:31) Ch 2 - DNS
⌨️ (0:48:11) Ch 3 - URIs and URLs
⌨️ (1:16:21) Ch 4 - Async JavaScript
⌨️ (1:49:48) Ch 5 - Errors in JS
⌨️ (2:04:54) Ch 6 - HTTP Headers
⌨️ (2:21:04) Ch 7 - JSON
⌨️ (2:41:09) Ch 8 - HTTP Methods
⌨️ (3:17:01) Ch 9 - URL Paths
⌨️ (3:36:33) Ch 10 - HTTPS security
⌨️ (3:48:24) Proj - Setup Dev Environment
⌨️ (3:51:28) Proj - Hello World
⌨️ (3:56:29) Proj - Normalize URLs
⌨️ (4:11:05) Proj - URLs from HTML
⌨️ (4:27:49) Proj - The main.js file
⌨️ (4:33:10) Proj - Using Fetch
⌨️ (4:45:16) Proj - Recursively crawling the web
⌨️ (4:55:33) Proj - Print an SEO report
⌨️ (5:06:59) Proj - Conclusion
⌨️ (5:08:04) Congratulations

Documentation used:
Fetch API: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API
URL constructor: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URL/URL
Fetch Rseponse: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Response

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Nattira Maneerat
👾 Heather Wcislo
👾 Serhiy Kalinets
👾 Erdeniz Unvan
👾 Justin Hual
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 Otis Morgan

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Daven L
topLevelComment.text:
For those wanting the extra stimulation in terms of learning, I recommend trying to follow along with a twist: getting everything working in TypeScript. That way you're forced to pay attention instead of blindly copying the tutorial. 

You may need something like this when running the main.ts file and wanting to silence the experimental errors:

cross-env NODE_OPTIONS=--no-warnings ts-node main.ts

topLevelComment.author: PEDRO RAMOS ALONSO
topLevelComment.text:
Rookie here. I have a doubt with the first exercise (1-web-communication). When I run it, it throws an error indicating that await is only valid in an asynchronous function. When getting the value of items, the function called by getItemData() is asynchronous. So, why is not working? Thanks in advance. Regards. 

P

replies.author: PEDRO RAMOS ALONSO
replies.text:
@Angmar Liche Thank you for your response. The problem happens in time https://youtu.be/2JYT5f2isg4?t=567. Here is the trace:  

Uncaught SyntaxError /fcc-learn-http-assets/course/1-why-http/exercises/1-web-communication/complete.js:2
const items = await getItemData()
              ^^^^^

SyntaxError: await is only valid in async function
    at wrapSafe (undefined:915:16)
    at Module._compile (undefined:963:27)
    at Module._extensions..js (undefined:1027:10)
    at Module.load (undefined:863:32)
    at Module._load (undefined:708:14)
    at executeUserEntryPoint (undefined:60:12)
    at <anonymous> (undefined:17:47)

I am using the node.js runtime environment

topLevelComment.author: Harsh Tekwani
topLevelComment.text: even if you put 0 in setTimeout call back function will only run ones js runtime call stack gets empty because until then it will be in callback queue and event loop will keep looking for call stack to get empty and then push call back function in it to get executed.

topLevelComment.author: Cody Shaner
topLevelComment.text:
Right off the bat, I get an error with the await clause of the first exercise.

I can't use await at line 2 -
 
"
const items = await getItemData();
              ^^^^^

SyntaxError: await is only valid in async functions and the top level bodies of
modules
"

Not sure why this is happening because of the async function that it's "awaiting" -- any thoughts?

replies.author: Cody Shaner
replies.text:
I was writing a js file and calling it with node

The Fix:
run npm init to generate a package.json

add the line -  "type": "module" to it

topLevelComment.author: Truth Teachers
topLevelComment.text: Bro, may i assist in explaining the word protocol a bit more clearer? The word protocol was derived from the politics. In politics, protocols are an established standard way to approach a country to have access to whatever is needed by another another country. Example, the Prime Minister of UK has to follow a set of protocols to establish contact with the President of the US. Similarly, HTTP is a protocol to be used in order for one technology entity to access the resources of another entity. When we use HTTP to get a web page, we do exactly this. Our browser use a set protocols (HTTP) to establish a communication into another machine to obtain access to a page in that machine.  Correct me if i am wrong.

replies.author: Boot dev
replies.text: I reached out to Beau to see if we can get them added!

topLevelComment.author: Максим М
topLevelComment.text:
Well, I can say with confidence, that we are witnessing a redefinition of the world current teaching standards. To be honest, I am abit angry that such amazing content is now up for free, when I'm already in my 3rd year degree in Software Eng, but on the bright side, the future gen won't be limited to financial/degree and even location restraints.
Some would say that I'm "selfish" or sth, and to a degree I do agree with them. 
Nevertheless the facts are that you are truly delivering knowledge to the ones in need, to whom my "prestegeous" course isn't available, and probabbly even delivering better materials than what a university offers. At the end of the day, you are trully doing an amazing job, and that's what's most important.

replies.author: 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁𝘀.𝗔𝗽𝗽me+①⑧⑦⓪②⑦①③②③⓪

replies.author: Divya Reddy
replies.text: @Akshay Joshi i can search the content on YouTube while arguing in the comment section. these two aren't mutually exclusive.

replies.author: pstcontrl
replies.text: @Pajeet Singh TCP/IP is not going anywhere any time soon.  In fact, consider yourself lucky that you got a chance to learn TCP/IP before it became "uncool".  There was a time when networking and devOps (before the term existed) felt like you do know when IPv 6 came out.  After all these years, IPv 4 is still more common and can't do much without knowing IPv 4.  I know things move a bit quicker in the application layer thanks to all the abstraction, but still, you will not regret learning TCP/IP.  I'm an old guy, and I often wish I learned some of the older technologies, even the obsolete ones because they give you a different look and help you think outside the box.

replies.author: Akshay Joshi

topLevelComment.author: N0 Escape_200
topLevelComment.text:
Dumb question 
Can everything, that he's presenting in the video, be applied in React ?
I'm about to learn it and this course looks very interesting.

replies.author: Boot dev
replies.text: 100%. This video teaches HTTP from the client side, and React is on the client side. It's also super important for back-end engineers though, because you need to know how a client interacts with your servers.

replies.author: isaac Азимов
replies.text: You're good to go bro

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: Yes, HTTP is used for all web technologies so this course also applies to React development.
